rComments: Best professor in UOFT, with his motivation and concepts, all of his students will remember him as not just a teacher, but a life director.

He does not really prepare much about the course, he just indulge in his own talking. Do not be fooled by his philosophy, he can be very self righteous, mean and arrogant. But take it if you just need a credit, just memorize what he says during lecture, there is no need to do much extra work, do not offend him, and you will be fine.
EASY TO PASS EASY GRADED

Prof Shen is like the grandfather I never had  dude must be at least 80 years old! His experience and age adds a great level of charm to his lectures. He's very passionate about what he teaches, and totally kind and approachable. His grading criteria and tests are really fair.  All in all, brilliant course and professor! :D

The only professor I truly embraced and have the deepest respect for. His knowledge, his humbleness, his life work of generosity. It is true that his class can be challenging for non-natives and potentially boring, but if you are truly interested in Chinese philosophy and want to get your money's worth, there is simply no better professor than Shen
Nice prof. not hard to get a high mark.
so boring... he is enjoying himself teaching

Pure memorization but easy as 20% of mark is attendence. You dont need to know jack about mandarin to do well. Although, Shen can be hard to understand at times, its not about his accent but understanding philosophical concepts. I know Chinese and honestly, what he sprouts  in chinese doesn't make much difference to his lessons.

i don't speak a word of mandarin and i had no trouble with his accent. a true poly-math. the spectrum of his knowledge is truly profound. the man has degrees in 3 different languages. you get out what you put in to his man's courses. a true teacher as his genius is only surpassed by his benevolent and joyful manner. a pleasure to learn from.

if you have him...RUN!!  had him twice this year (unknowingly) Can't understand a thing he says because he mixes hindi, mandarin, english, german,and french while teaching.  Tests are mostly memorization and regurgitation.  A nice guy and definitely knows his stuff...but a terrible teacher.
The course is easy to pass and even to do well in, but is as dull as watching paint dry. This one had 20% just for turning up and signing register.
hell of a great prof, an excellent teacher and a very knowledgeble person

the prof is actually very knowledgeable,but is unfortunately quite difficult to understand at times since he tends to switch back and forth between mandarin and english,but i think a lot of it can't be helped as there are no translations on names and some concepts, it's quite easy to get a good mark
This course allows me to understand better Confucianism, Daoism and Buddhism in Chinese philosophical tradition and thereby I understand Chinese culture in a deeper way.
Ditto what everyone else said. I speak Mandarin, but I still couldn't understand him when he's speaking English!!

His accent is hard to understand and he tends to switch back and forth between Chinese and English. Also, he is mind-numbingly boring (which is no small feat, considering that the subject matter is potentially so interesting). Oh, and marks attendance!
Very easy going prof with an easy distribution of marks going..c'mon, attendance is worth 25% alone!  I went everyday for 10 min just for the hell of it
I do speak Mandarin and find him actually very knowledgeable. And indeed a very easy-going prof.

Interesting course material taught by an interesting man.  Some knowledge of Mandarin may be helpful, as he has a tendancy to digress into Chinese only. . . . 'Hindeseglish' may be helpful for discussion of Buddhism.
very strange and insists on taking attendance in lectures... if anyone finds out what the *@#$ a  bhudatatata  is, let us know!
LOOK at past tests, his accent is a bit tough to decifer
You have to read the lecture notes... easy tests...
Horrible accent, but easy going prof. Lecture notes more important than lectures
No Comments
